review_title: It’s can be a good experience

cons: UR is very stuck in their ways. It’s hard to introduce new things or ideas. This university can also be very cliquish if you’re new. If you’re entry level you may feel belittled by the older staff.

review_title: Good money, many good people, terrible administration
pros: Salaries here tend to be higher than other colleges and universities in the region. Employees have received raises all but one of the past 10 years and retirement contributions from the university have remained intact when many others have cut them.
cons: Vacation is stingy compared to other colleges and universities in the region. Inflexible policies re: telework, even after employees have successfully proven it can work during the pandemic. Upper administrators are politically out of touch with the rest of the employees and students.

review_title: Working at the University of Richmond has significantly benefitted me both personally and professionally.
pros:
The university leadership creates a positive, growing work environment. People who work here are grateful for their careers and feel like they are a part of something greater that is a benefit to the larger community. 
After you master your current position, there are plenty of opportunities to grow laterally by giving back or being creative within the community. I wear many different hats on campus, including my current position, orientation, and even working with student organizations.  
For two years, human resources did a salary review in which the staff salaries were compared with comparable and regional colleges, local businesses, etc., and after the study 49% of staff received some measure of an increase in compensation. If you are full time, and sometimes even part-time, you can earn a good salary with good benefits.
The community is encouraged to build itself here. We have numerous events throughout the year to bring our division or divisions together to celebrate our successes. People are encouraged to diminish silos and work together to increase campus-wide communication and open engagement. It has led to a great community on campus.
cons: As with the national trend, after the 2008 recession many of the folks who would normally retire or move up to senior positions have not because of the decrease in their retirement packages. If we sustain continued economic growth, this pattern ought to rectify itself, but currently there is not much vertical opportunity.

pros: The great thing about working here is that you get free tuition.  The university has great professors.  The work=life balance was good, enabling you to work, go to school at night and still have time for your family
cons: I found that most employees had been there for a very long time.  I found this to be a problem because they were not interested in learning new ways of doing things or being open to new ideas.  There is a lack of cultural diversity in the workforce and among the student body and I did not find the work to be challenging.

review_title: Nice Access to Amenities but Management was Shady
pros: Great amenities. Awesome health and Rec facility. Great places to eat on campus. Campus itself is beautiful. Sports are all solid and we get tickets to all home contests. Tuition reimbursement is also really nice if you are looking at grad education. Richmond is a fun town with lots to do and great culture.
cons: The administering was notoriously shady and the pay is only equal to what you see at comparable mid majors. This was surprising considering the schools resources compared to other mid majors. Granted I was there 2014-2016 and there’s been turn over in many of the top positions.

review_title: An amazing place to work and grow.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in University of Richmond, VA
pros: The culture and environment are both fantastic. The faculty, staff and students are fun and interesting to work with. A lot of opportunities for growth in your personal and professional life. You really have the sense that the university cares about you and your family. There are a lot of extra benefits and events the university does to make you feel welcome and a part of the community. Beautiful campus and access to a lot of free or cheap services.
cons: Depending on your role your compensation may not be competitive with the average pay in Richmond.

review_title: Great summer work as a student
pros: flexible, great coworkers, compensation, understanding environment, room for advancement, departments work together, high ranked departments compared to national standards
cons: some outdated practices, dependence on the board of trustees

review_title: Do perks balance out low salaries?  Depends on your situation.
pros: Beautiful campus, friendly, collegial coworkers, great benefits and all the perks you get working for a college.
cons: Staff salaries below market, usual politics of academia, some staff seem to hoard knowledge.

review_title: Good Place to Earn Extra Cash
pros:
Flexible hours allow you to balance work and class
Management that supports employees and looks out for their best interests
Develop communication skills (and sometimes contacts) that can benefit you in future employment
cons:
Sometimes can get extremely repetitive and boring on bad calling nights now that internet use is restricted
Compensation through bonuses seems to be decreasing

pros: Small school with a family atmosphere.  You get to know everyone by name. Great perks such as professional development.  Annual salary increases that range from 2% to 5% depending on performance. University provides 5% of salary to the retirement plan and an additional match up to 5% more.
cons: Although becoming more diverse, there are still some departments that do not have any diverse staff.  Staff sometimes feel second-rate to faculty

review_title: Rewarding, professional environment. Great for life long learners.
pros: Collegial staff, flexible work environment and schedule, great benefits as far as colleges and universities go. Opportunity for continued education.
cons: No/minimal training or development programs. No clear advancement opportunities for staff.

review_title: Great opportunity for college students that excel at general chemistry
job_title: General Chemistry Tutor in Richmond, VA
pros: This is a part-time job that has good hours, and a lot of support from the Chemistry department.  Easy to work in time for studies.
cons: There is only one other person that holds the position for review sessions so hours are not the most flexible.  You should not look in to this job if this does not fit your schedule.

pros:
- Very friendly staff -- Jeanne is great!
- Get to pick your own hours that you're available to work
- If you enjoy public speaking, you'll have fun at your job too!
cons:
- Work hours are dependent upon people making appointments (and you only get paid for appointments)
- Prerequisite classes are required to become a Speech Consultant (but this is expected, and increases the prestige!)

review_title: Love UR but do not pay students well
pros: The tutoring is fun and you met the best people. Your "bosses" are great and will help you apply for full-time jobs and help you however they can.
cons: You start at $8/hour as a tutor and do not get moved up to a "Tutor Supervisor" until you are a senior or grad student.

cons: Dealing with drunk people, having some party hard residents hate you, having to unlock stupid residents doors, bi-weekly journals, weekly meetings, coming back to campus early
